Instrument_PDS3.instrument_desc:
INSTRUMENT DESCRIPTION ======================
These data are molecular (spectral line-SL) observations. These data are archived in FITS format as one-dimensional spectra of the flux density of the comet as a function of the line of sight velocity. For most SL observations, the line of sight velocity is given with respect to the observer, although some observers transmitted their results to us in terms of the geocentric velocity.
Some SL observations were conducted using two receivers having orthogonal polarizations. In order to preserve this information, we have presented the polarized spectral data in a two dimensional format with a second axis to designate which polarization applies. These spectra will have the NAXIS keyword set equal to 2, and the second axis will be labeled either ' CIRCULAR POLARIZATION' or 'LINEAR POLARIZATION'. This method for designationg polarization is similar to the convention used in many FITS formats, where a seperate axis (often labeled 'STOKES') is used to give the full Stokes parameters of the data. However, full Stokes parameters have not measured in this archive, and so we have defined these new polarization axes to handle this situation.

SCIENTIFIC OBJECTIVES =====================
Radio Astronomy is a developing new technique for the study of comets. In some areas, such as observations of the OH radical via its 18 cm transitions, the observational procedures and analysis are well developed. Studies in these areas have proved their value since they both provide new probes of important physical processes as well as a window on physical processes which are less well known and less accessible to study by other techniques. In many other areas, however, the study of comets at radio wavelengths continues to be primarily an exploratory endeavor. In recognition of this fact, the IHW Radio Science Discipline Specialist team felt that it was important to attempt many different kinds of observations during this campaign on Halley's Comet, since each observation has scientific merit as an exploration. Thus, we have been careful to document and include all data submitted to this archive by radio observers.
The P/Halley Archive contains data from 36 different observing groups, representing a range of techniques. The majority of the observational data come in the well developed area of 18cm OH observations. However, many other projects were attempted as well. Approximately 75% of the groups who are known to have obtained useful data on the comet have submitted it to the archive, and we are grateful to them for their contributions.
